title: Stocks TurnUpward as Bond Yields Swing; The 10-year Treasury yield briefly rose above 4% Wednesday before falling
text:
The Nasdaq Composite, which also fell at the open, rose 0.6% by midmorning.

Bond yields swiveled after the Bank of England said it would begin buying U.K. government bonds in a bid to stabilize markets. In the U.S., the yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note briefly climbed above 4% for the first time in more than a decade before slipping down again.

Stocks have come under increasing pressure as investors focus on soaring inflation and central banks' efforts to fight it with higher interest rates. More signs are pointing to slowing economic growth, including, by one measure, the first monthly decline in house prices in years.

In recent days, investors have turned their attention to the U.K. The British government last week unveiled the country's biggest tax cuts in decades. The news spooked investors and sent the yield on the 10-year sovereign bond soaring.

The situation lifted interest rates elsewhere, including the U.S. And as rates climbed, investors had more places to put their money for returns and stocks looked more expensive.

On Wednesday, though, bond yields came back to earth after the Bank of England said it would buy U.K. government bonds with long maturities "on whatever scale is necessary." That helped lift U.S. stocks, said David Lefkowitz, head of U.S. equities for UBS's global wealth management business.

"For the last several trading days, the pressure on U.S. stocks has been a reflection of some of the turmoil in the fixed-income market," Mr. Lefkowitz said. "As that turmoil settles down, we're seeing a better tone for equities."

The yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note also fell after soaring early in the morning. Yields rise when bond prices fall.

"There's fear that the whole system collapses and demand is not able to withstand this amount of rate hikes," said Agnes Belaisch, a chief strategist at Barings Investment Institute. "There are pieces of evidence out there that could be signs of recession."

The British pound weakened 0.7% against the dollar after the International Monetary Fund said the country should re-evaluate its controversial fiscal plan. Rating company Moody's said the budget is credit negative.

Global crude-oil benchmark Brent rose 0.9% to trading at $85.67 a barrel. A European natural-gas benchmark rose 3% amid escalating threats to the region's energy supply.

The damage to the Nord Stream pipelines which deliver Russian gas to central Europe was the result of sabotage, EU President Ursula von der Leyen posted on Twitter. Russian state-owned Gazprom issued what analysts said appeared to be a threat to cut exports of the fuel through Ukraine.

Porsche's initial public offering, Europe's largest such deal this year, is expected to price later on Wednesday and the shares will start trading on the Frankfurt exchange the next day.

In U.S. trading, shares of Biogen were up 39% after the company said its experimental Alzheimer's drug significantly slowed the disease's progression in a large study. Its partner in the study, Japanese pharmaceutical company Eisai, rose 17% in Tokyo trading.

Apple shares slipped 3.2% after Bloomberg reported that the company is dropping plans to boost iPhone production.

Overseas, the pan-continental Stoxx Europe 600 declined 0.5%. In Asia, most major benchmarks also fell. The Shanghai Composite Index lost 1.6% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index declined 3.4%.
